fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50687].
  {panel}

h3.Problem

Once you've setup a JIRA Calender with a few issues to retrieve Confluence Team Calendars keeps spinning and takes some time to load the events.

It depends on how much events you are picking up from JIRA.

This has some connection to TEAMCAL-646 but does not need to be custom fields.

h3.Steps to reproduce(assuming that you have a working version of Confluence, and have already installed Team Calendars)

# Setup Application links with jira.atlassian.com
# Configure this newly created link, and go to "Outgoing Authentication"
# Go to "Basic Access" and use your own credentials for jira.atlassian.com
# Create a new Calendar, Select JIRA Calendar
# Name as you want, no need for description or space.
# Server, select Atlassian JIRA
# Display, Saved filter and type CONF Top... and it should bring CONF Top Voted New Features and Improvements, select this
# Select all check boxes.
# Save

Now it will take about 10 seconds to load all events, sometimes more.

h3.Workaround
There is none yet
fields.summary: Improve JIRA Calendar Performance

fields.description:
To reproduce: 
# Embed a calendar in a wiki page using "week view." 
# Create a 1 hour (or longer) event that is not an all day event. 
# Hover your mouse over the lower middle of the event (your cursor will turn into a small down arrow). 
# Click and drag downward, as if to lengthen (add time) to the meeting. 
# You will notice: 
#* your meeting has not been extended. 
#* your meeting has actually been reduced to a half hour. 

I'll try to attach a screen video soon.
fields.summary: the ajax "drag to extend time" function in week view is broken
Drag and drop is not working with Confluence 4.3

fields.description:
Using the latest calendars on EAC. To reproduce:

1. Open your calendar and add the "PM Team Leave" calendar, then uncheck it to hide the events from that calendar. At this point your calendar view should be empty.
2. Create a "new" people calendar.
3. After the new calendar is created it will appear in the "my calendars" and the PM Team Leave calendar events will re-appear but the calendar is still shown as being "hidden" in the people calendar list to the right.

Seems like the refresh after adding a calendar is ignoring the visibility configuration for the other existing people calendars.

h5. Finding
The plugin can be installed and enabled flawlessly in Confluence 3.5.2 onwards.

h5. Workaround
Upgrade to Confluence 3.5.2 or higher in the meantime.

Yongpyo Hong

fields.summary: PopularSubCalendarSubscription does not implement java.io.Serializable

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50643].
  {panel}

The extractor is falling over when it encounters a reference to a a user that does not exist, e.g. a user that has been deleted from LDAP.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50640].
  {panel}

When trying to add a Team Calendar into Google calendar gives "The address that you provided did not contain a calendar in a valid iCal or GData format."

Here the steps I took to reproduce the issue.

1. Create a new events calendar upon Team Calendar
2. Click on the new calendar and click in Subscribe
3. Copy the URL
4. Go to Google Calendar and go other Calendar -> Add it by URL
5. Paste the URL and click on Add Calendar

The same issue was opened before in Confluence project: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-24764

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50637].
  {panel}

h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create an event that spans across 2 days at minimum, example: May 16th - May 17th
# Embed the Calendar into a Confluence page that allows an anonymous user to view anonymously
# Logout, and view the page anonymously

h3.Observed Behavior
While viewing anonymously, this is shown:
!teamcalendars2.jpg!

But once logged in, the issue disappears:
!teamcalendars1.jpg!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50633].
  {panel}

Hi,

Our calendars are all internal (i.e. vacation, corporate events, etc.), and so we need to restrict access to these from non-employee users such as our clients, partners, etc. I tried looking for admin permissions to configure this but couldn't find any, the only option I did find is calendar specific restrictions but even that did not help me hide our calendars. How can I hide the plugin completely from some users/groups?

Thanks,
Roei

fields.description:
Run the attached script with the attached ical import. After about 50 imports you will run out of heap space. This is probably because the cache will cache up to 1000 calendar objects regardless of size, so if you import a bunch of very large calendars in less then an hour you may run out of memory.

This is probably not a realistic usage senario, but I this test might be useful if we need to address scalability.
fields.summary: You can run out of heap space when importing many large calendars in Confluence

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50600].
  {panel}

Hi, I thought this will be a better platform to raise this concern instead of Atlassian Answers.

It is possible to subscribe team calendars on Google Calendars with a url e.g
http://<confluence site>/rest/calendar-services/1.0/calendar/export/subcalendar/private/qascdtgbhfff19564cd25efghj68fd2b649kjhg9.ics

I tested this out on a browser without Confluence log in, and it is possible to download the ics file.

This means that it is possible to get confidential calendar information with a brute force dictionary attack. This is especially so when the length of the file is 40 characters.

Is there any way of preventing this? Or Whether we can turn off the subscribe feature without breaking other parts?

fields.description:
A Confluence user that isn't a member of a project in Jira can see a Jira calendar related with that project when adding a calender. However, if he adds the calender, dates from this calendar don't show up. But I'd expected that the non-project member doesn't see this project at all.

What's even worse is, that the non-project member has the choice to delete this project calendar for all users when he wants to remove that calendar again. And if he chooses to delete the calendar, the calendar is actually removed for all users.
fields.summary: Jira calendars are visible to non-project members

fields.description:
It affects JIRA Calendars as well.

To reproduce the problem:
# Create an issue in JIRA with non-English characters (like Russian) in the summary
# Create a JIRA calendar that pulls in the issue as an event

The problem lies within the iCalendar stream encoding detection in Team Calendars. That failure caused Team Calendars to fallback on 'ISO-8859-1' (which isn't right).
fields.summary: Non-English characters of events coming from external calendars displayed as odd symbols

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50585].
  {panel}

Seems to affect all versions of the JIRA calendar and Team Calendars plugins. 

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Create a project in JIRA (let's call it TEST), and add 3 versions to that project (example: v1, v2, v3)
# Add a Version Release Date to each version
# Create 3 issues under the project, each linked to 1 unique fixVersion (example: Issue1's fixVersion=v1, Issue2's fixVersion=v2, Issue3's fixVersion=v3) 
# Create a JIRA Calendar in Team Calendars (in Confluence), with the following JQL:
{code}
project = TEST AND fixVersion = v1
{code}
Make sure that the *Version Due Date* checkbox is ticked.

Notice that the Version Release Date is shown for all 3 versions, when we are only interested in one. 

Actually, I'm not too sure whether this is an expected behavior or a bug, since the fixVersion field is mostly used only to filter issues, not specifically to filter version release dates.
fields.summary: JQL filter does not work for Version Due Date (if you wish to filter based on versions)

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50574].
  {panel}

As far as I can tell, there are two ways to view a calendar in Confluence: 
# Add it to my "calendars" view. 
# Render it in a confluence page using the \{calendar\} macro. 

This latter approach only allows me to render a single calendar in a page. I'd like the ability to render more than one calendar in a wiki page. The old calendar plugin provided this, and it was a nice feature. It allows an easy way to show several related calendars in a single view without the need to have every single person replicate that view on their own.
fields.summary: Add ability to render multiple calendars in a single calendar macro in-page

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-50571].
  {panel}

On adding a new events to a people calendar and entering a user's name in the "Who" row only resolves users from the Internal Confluence directory. Users from the configured active directory can only be found when entering the userid, e.g.

+Active Directory+
Userid: tkrug0210
User Name: Thomas Krug
Entering "Thomas" or "Krug" returns no result. Entering "tkrug0210" shows my account. 

+Internal Directory+
Userid: admin
User Name: Confluence administrator
The user is found with any string "confluence", "conf", "admin", "administrator" etc.

h3.Workaround
Upgrade to JIRA 5.0 or higher, which is compatible with JIRA Calendar Plugin version 1.19, which do not have this issue.

*OR*

Downgrade the Team Calendars plugin in Confluence to version 2.3.2 (Uninstall the 2.4.0 plugin from {{Confluence Admin >> Plugins >> Team Calendars}}, before installing version 2.3.2 of the plugin obtained here: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/download/plugins/com.atlassian.confluence.extra.team-calendars/version/1302)
